div1.p: Lyons discusses the Reed exhibit being prepared for the Hall of Fame.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 22, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME : NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
22 April 1948
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am just in receipt of your letter of April 20. I
am delighted to learn that you are coming by train to the ceremony
instead of by plane. It certainly will give you a chance to rest
and somehow I feel that the trains really are on time. If you will
be good enough to advise me where you expect to stay in New York, or
at what hour you expect to arrive, then I can make the necessary
arrangements for picking you up in one of the cars.

As to the Congressional Medal, we have found a good
spot for it in the program and only yesterday I communicated with
Mr. Berkeley, the Curator at the University of Virginia, asking him
to be good enough to give me a clearer photostat of it. The one
which they previously sent was very inadequate. Mr. Berkeley, I
might add, was very gracious and is going to send me the photostats
before the weekend.

I assume you have not yet heard from General Reed
regarding the wording of the courtesy lines in the program for
material furnished by him relating to his father. When you have this
information, will you be good enough to send it on to me because I
am now getting ready to prepare the captions for the cuts and manu-
scripts. The program is now well under way. The engraver has just
reduced the manuscripts with deletions and the cuts are being made.
The complete text is also now in the hands of the printer.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director BLL:yz
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
